taskDescription:
The moon is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>3.844</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mn>8</mn>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">3.844 \times {10^8}</annotation></semantics></math> m from Earth. A dollar bill has a thickness of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow>
  <mn>1.0922</mn>
  <mo>×<!-- × --></mo>
  <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
    <msup>
      <mn>10</mn>
      <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
        <mo>−<!-- − --></mo>
        <mn>4</mn>
      </mrow>
    </msup>
  </mrow>
</mrow><annotation encoding="LaTeX">1.0922 \times {10^{ - 4}}</annotation></semantics></math> m. If dollar bills could be stacked perfectly, how many would it take to reach the moon?
